dt.t: were {wi}overcome{/wi} by the heat and smoke
strong in the faith that truth would {wi}overcome{/wi}

pt: {sc}conquer{/sc} {sc}vanquish{/sc} {sc}defeat{/sc} {sc}subdue{/sc} {sc}reduce{/sc} {sc}overcome{/sc} {sc}overthrow{/sc} mean to get the better of by force or strategy. {sc}conquer{/sc} implies gaining mastery of.

pt.t: {it}vanquished{/it} the enemy and ended the war

pt: {sc}defeat{/sc} does not imply the finality or completeness of {sc}vanquish{/sc} which it otherwise equals.

pt.t: the Confederates {it}defeated{/it} the Union forces at Manassas
{it}subdued{/it} the native tribes after years of fighting

pt: {sc}reduce{/sc} implies a forcing to capitulate or surrender.

pt.t: the city was {it}reduced{/it} after a month-long siege

pt: {sc}overcome{/sc} suggests getting the better of with difficulty or after hard struggle.
{sc}overthrow{/sc} stresses the bringing down or destruction of existing power.

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}ofercuman{/it}, from {it}ofer{/it} over + {it}cuman{/it} to come
shortdef: to get the better of : surmount
